text: So hedging is something that we do on a team basis because it's really important to look at the entire risk of the portfolio, not just any particular trade or strategy. So based on the entire portfolio, you want to be sizing and implementing your hedges. Now, for the why we run tail hedging, there's two big reasons. So the first one is like the obvious direct benefit that you get, that hopefully during a period of market stress, you're less correlated. You're taking a smaller loss. You don't find yourself in a big hole that you have to dig yourself out of. But the second one, which I think is much less appreciated, is that when you have some hedges on, it helps you take advantage of the market opportunities that come up. And what I mean by that is that, look, if you're down a lot, you're not mentally going to be in a good position to take advantage of whatever opportunities are coming your way. I really like the Walter Diemer quote that when the time comes to buy, you won't want to. But instead, if you're in a position where the hedging is not going to happen, you're going to have to take advantage of the market opportunities that come up. So I think heads are helping you. And you can look at what opportunities are out there, and you can add positions that much more attractive levels. So, you know, we don't see hedges as a profit center over time. I expect that our hedges will generally lose money, at least in isolation. We've actually done better than that. But certainly that's not something that you want to build in. But more importantly, hedging gives you this mental edge of being able to take on more risk when other market opportunities are just going to do better. participants might not be able to because of financial constraints or psychological reasons. Now for the how we implement hedging, we have sort of three main types. So the first market risk is gap risk. So that is like we've talked about a good examples of October 1987 and March 2020, where there's like a huge move in markets accompanied with a jump in volatility. And so for those kinds of events, you typically want to have a long volatility hedge that has a nice meaningful payoff in a crisis period, but that you can hold in non-crisis periods and not have a huge drag. The second type of hedge is against more sort of gradual and slower moves, whether up or down. So an example of that is stocks in 2008, 2009, where they tended to grind lower until they hit the bottom of the Dow Jones index. And then the second type of hedge is against aら to drive up for a while, but then tend to drive down to the bottom. So we've seen that in the last year pretty consistently, commodity prices have gone up, bonds have gone lower. So that's been a good environment for most trend and CTA type strategies, and that's been a good portfolio hedge, even during periods where vol has not necessarily been as reactive. The third type of hedge is the hardest. It's around events. So for that is where you're looking at the world today, and you're gonna think of like what's what's the market like for stock prices like, and saying that there's a market is not really pricing in that the world could look quite different in the future. Going back to what I was saying at the beginning around taking a look at the entire city from a sky that you could see that right now there's no traffic but you could also model in that maybe there's no traffic at noon but at 5 p.m. there is going to be. And a good example of that would be what's happened with bonds. So a year ago, not only were bond yields low but bond implied volatilities were also low. So you could structure something that you would have a nice payoff if rates were to rise but with a fixed known downside cost. So that was a good example of an advantage but I will say that they tend to be the hardest because you need to get not only at least directionally the timing and predict what's gonna happen in the future but you also need to structure in a way that you get a better chance of getting a payoff that's much greater than what the odds of that happening is much greater than the market is anticipating.
